question: Imagine you are a member of the Chateau Clique writing a private letter about the ongoing conflict with the Patriotes and the struggles with French Canadians.
gold_answer: Private Letter — The situation grows tenser with each passing day. The Patriotes, emboldened by the support of their French Canadian base, stand in direct conflict with us. Their victories, such as at St Denis, have only strengthened their resolve. Our efforts are met with resistance, and the Assembly’s complaints about the expenditure of public moneys without the consent of the Executive government complicate matters further. The British government, for its part, continues to keep loyal to French Canadians, but their loyalty to the British crown is being sorely tested.
llm_answer:
Château de Ramezay, Montréal  
3rd December, 1837  

My dear McTavish,  

I write in haste, by the same courier who carries the Governor’s dispatches, lest this letter be intercepted by the rebels’ patrols that now infest the road to Québec.  

The state of the country is worse than any of us anticipated.  The French populace, long flattered by Papineau’s harangues, has at last thrown off the mask of loyalty.  From Berthier to Sorel every seigneur’s bell is silent, while the curés who once preached obedience now openly bless pikes and pitchforks.  At St-Denis last month we saw what this means: Nelson’s ruffians, drilled like regulars, held the river bridge against Colborne’s flank companies for six hours, and it was only the 32nd with a section of Royal Artillery that forced the passage.  I lost two good friends in that skirmish—Lieutenant Ermatinger among them—and I confess the smell of burnt powder has not yet left my coat.  

The Assembly, as you know, has become a mere theatre for Papineau’s tirades.  His “Ninety-Two Resolutions” are nothing but a declaration that the old constitution is dead and that the habitants are the true heirs of the soil.  When the Russell Resolutions reached us in March the Patriotes declared a boycott on every article that bears the King’s mark; in Montréal their “Fils de la Liberté” parade the streets at night, smashing the windows of any merchant who dares import British calico.  We have formed the Doric Club in answer—two hundred of us, all old Loyalist families, sworn to keep the peace—but we are out-numbered and, I fear, out-gunned.  

The Church, thank God, still stands firm.  Mgr Lartigue has forbidden his priests to countenance rebellion, and Abbé Paquin at St-Eustache preached against the insurgents only last Sunday.  Yet even there Chartier, the renegade curé, harangued the congregation after mass, bidding them take up arms “for the faith of their fathers.”  Such is the impudence of the times.  

I cannot conceal from you my private apprehension.  The country is ripe for a second 1775: the French remember how Montgomery walked unopposed up the frozen St Lawrence, and they believe the same road lies open to Papineau if once the snow sets in.  Colborne does his best, but with fewer than twelve hundred regulars scattered from Gaspé to Kingston he must rely on the militia—and how many of our own tenants will march when their cousins stand in the rebel ranks?  

Should the worst befall, I have made my own dispositions.  The plate and the family papers go to-night by sloop to Québec; my wife and the children will follow as soon as the river is clear of drift-ice.  For myself, I remain at my post: the old seigneurial oath binds me to the soil, and I will not quit while one stone of the Château stands upon another.  Yet I pray that His Majesty’s Government may send us reinforcements—red-coats, not words—before the spring thaws, else I fear we shall witness the tricolour, not the Union Jack, floating above the citadel.  

Keep this letter close; burn it if danger threatens.  If I fall, remember me to the Club as one who held his ground.  

Yours in loyalty and affliction,  

(Signed)  
A——  
Deputy for Montréal County  
& Member of His Majesty’s Executive Council
